question.text: Which of the following transition metals is most likely to appear colorless?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving transition metals , recall that although most transition metals form colored complexes, row 4 transition metals are an exception to this rule and appear colorless. From the answer choices, V (Vanadium) is the only transition metal found in row 4. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: Which of the following elements is classified as a lanthanide?

explanation.concept_text: Option A. Na Incorrect. Na is found in group 1 of the periodic table and is therefore classified as an alkali metal . Option B. Ca Incorrect. Ca is found in group 2 of the periodic table and is therefore classified as an alkaline earth metal . Option C. Cu Incorrect. Cu is found in group 11 of the periodic table and is therefore classified as a transition metal . Option D. Eu Correct. Eu is found in period 6 of the inner transition metals and is therefore classified as a lanthanide . Inner transition metals are found on the bottommost section of the periodic table. Option E. Am Incorrect. Am is found in period 7 of the inner transition metals and is therefore classified as an actinide . Inner transition metals are found on the bottommost section of the periodic table. Therefore, the answer is D .

question.text: Each of the following are properties of transition metals EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving transition metals , we must first familiarize ourselves with the physical and chemical properties of transition metals. Transition metals are the elements belonging to groups 3-12 of the periodic table, and their common properties include: In this case, each answer choice correctly describes the properties of transition metals except for choice D (single oxidation state). Because transition metals have their outermost electrons in more than one orbital, transition metals often have multiple oxidation states . Therefore, the answer is D .

question.text: An unknown element is found to have multiple oxidation states. This element is most likely

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving oxidation states , we must identify the transition metal from the answer choices provided. This is because an important property of transition metals is that most have multiple oxidation states. If presented with a similar question on the exam in which you are asked to identify the element most likely to have multiple oxidation states, select the transition metal. Please note that while other elements on the periodic table exhibit multiple oxidation states as well, memorizing these exact elements is beyond the scope of the exam. Zn is the only transition metal from the answer choices provided. All the other elements listed are not classified as transition metals. Therefore, the answer is B .

question.text: Most transition metals readily form partially filled

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving transition metals , we must recognize that transition metals are characterized by their ability to form partially filled d -subshells . Note that transition metals are referred to as d -block elements because each successive element on the periodic table has an additional electron added to its outermost d -orbital. Therefore, the answer is C .

question.text: Which of the following is the most prominent oxidation state for transition metals?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving transition metals , recall that transition metals and inner transition metals often have multiple oxidation states . +2 is the most prominent oxidation state for transition metals, while +3 is the most prominent for inner transition metals. Therefore, the answer is B .

question.text: Each of the following transition metals are solids at room temperature EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving the properties of transition metals , we can recall that all transition metals are solids at room temperature, with the exception of mercury (Hg) . Excluding mercury, transition metals exhibit high melting and boiling points. In contrast, mercury’s melting point is approximately -39°C (-38.2°F). As a result, mercury is liquid at room temperature. Therefore, the correct answer is D .

question.text: An element has its outermost electrons in the f -orbital. This element would best be classified as

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving atomic orbitals , we should familiarize ourselves with the four blocks of the periodic table: the s -block, the p -block, the d -block, and the f -block. A block on the periodic table represents the atomic orbital that is in the process of being filled by the outermost electrons. The s -block is comprised of alkali metals (group 1) and alkaline earth metals (group 2). The p -block is comprised of all nonmetal elements (excluding hydrogen and helium), metalloids, and post-transition elements (groups 13-18). The d -block is comprised of transition metals (groups 3-12). The f- block is comprised of inner transition metals (periods 6 and 7 found in the bottommost section of the periodic table). Option A. an inner transition metal. Correct. Inner transition metals are found in the f -block and therefore the outermost electrons occupy the f -orbital. Option B. an alkali metal. Incorrect. Alkali metals are found in the s -block and therefore the outermost electrons occupy the s -orbital. Option C. a halogen. Incorrect. Halogens are found in the p -block and therefore the outermost electrons occupy the p -orbital. Option D. a transition metal. Incorrect. Transition metals are found in the d -block and therefore the outermost electrons occupy the d -orbital. Option E. a noble gas. Incorrect. Noble gases are found in the p -block and therefore the outermost electrons occupy the p -orbital. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: Habers process uses an iron catalyst for the large-scale production of ammonia from hydrogen and atmospheric nitrogen. Iron is classified as

explanation.concept_text: In this case, iron is found in group 8 of the periodic table and is classified as a transition metal . Therefore, the answer is E .

question.text: Each of the following statements is correct for inner transition metals EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Elements found in period 6 are classified as lanthanides.

options.label: B.
options.text: Elements found in period 7 are classified as actinides.

options.label: C.
options.text: They are more abundant on Earth than transition metals.

options.label: D.
options.text: Their most prominent oxidation state is +3.

options.label: E.
options.text: Their outermost electrons reside in the f -orbital.

correct_answer_text: They are more abundant on Earth than transition metals.

explanation.concept_text: Keep in mind that we need to identify the statement that is incorrect of inner transition metals. Option A. Elements found in period 6 are classified as lanthanides. Incorrect. Inner transition metals are found in the bottommost section of the periodic table and the elements in period 6 are classified as lanthanides. Option B. Elements found in period 7 are classified as actinides. Incorrect. Inner transition metals are found in the bottommost section of the periodic table and the elements in period 7 are classified as actinides. Option C. They are more abundant on Earth than transition metals. Correct. Inner transition metals are less abundant on earth than transition metals. Option D. Their most prominent oxidation state is +3. Incorrect. Transition metals often exhibit multiple oxidation states, and the most prominent oxidation state is +3. Option E. Their outermost electrons reside in the f-orbital. Incorrect. Successive electrons added to an inner transition element will reside in the outermost f -orbital. Therefore, the answer is C .
